executive_summary: Fuel dealers have exhibited revenue growth as demand has remained stable and oil and natural gas prices have fluctuated favorably. However, the COVID-19 pandemic disrupted demand for fuel from commercial and industrial operations as they shuttered or operated at reduced capacity. Oil prices plummeted amid the suspension of most travel and revenue plunged in 2020. Oil consumption from consumers quarantined at home helped stave off more severe losses, but this boon was dampened as most states were getting warmer through the height of stay-at-home ordinances. The Russia-Ukraine war has caused oil prices to surge since early 2022, but revenue has begun to decline again as production catches up. Revenue for fuel dealers is expected to climb at a CAGR of 2.9% to $49.0 billion through the end of 2024, including growth of 1.7% in 2024 alone.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The pandemic brought disruptions, even though fuel is essential
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Many consumers have annual contracts with fuel dealers to supply home heating fuel, making it a non-discretionary purchase. This typically protects fuel dealers from volatility, but the pandemic brought an atypical drop in fuel sales. Business closures and shelter-in-place orders substantially reduced demand from commercial customers. Household demand somewhat buoyed revenue, though, as consumers spent much more time at home and used more fuel.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Competition from natural gas will climb
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Since natural gas is less expensive and emits fewer greenhouse gases than heating oil, states like Connecticut and New Jersey have tried to extend natural gas lines to allow consumers to switch. While an increase in the number of housing starts typically helps fuel dealers, newly built homes in areas recently supplied by gas distribution networks may be more conducive to natural gas use because of price differentials.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Volatile oil and gas prices will continue to challenge the industry
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: While rising prices can boost short-term revenue, they also put pressure on profit because dealers aren't able to pass on all cost increases to consumers. Oil prices will continue to be volatile and are expected to climb because of the Palestine-Israel war. To counter this problem, fuel dealers must secure long-term supply contracts that shield themselves from future crude oil and natural gas price increases.

As the push for environmental sustainability strengthens, state and federal governments will implement stricter regulations for fuel dealers. These regulations will aim to limit the environmental impact of traditional fuels. Regulations can include enforcing strict emission standards, improving safety measures and mandating a higher proportion of biofuels and other renewable fuels in the energy mix.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Adopting new innovations will be a key strategy for growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Advancements in technology are introducing various innovations that will influence fuel dealers and support revenue growth. For instance, digital platforms are already simplifying ordering fuel and enhancing customer experience. Using sensors for remote monitoring of fuel tanks also optimizes supply chains and improves service efficiency. Introducing mobile fuel stations increases accessibility and convenience for customers.

industry_definition: This industry sells heating oil, propane and other fuels directly to end users. Related companies also deliver heating oil, propane and other fuels, such as autogas and kerosene, to domestic and commercial premises.
key_trends: The industry contends with growing competition from other heating systems. More households are switching to central electric heating because of its safety and advancement, which allows customers to easily control the temperature from their mobile devices.
Fuel dealers are insulated from some competition. Homes and businesses already equipped with oil heating systems aren't likely to be refitted with alternatives.

High oil prices have brought revenue growth for fuel dealers. Skyrocketing prices in the wake of the pandemic and a shortage amid the Russia-Ukraine war have made oil much more costly and fuel dealers have lifted prices accordingly.
Competition is ramping up. More and more new homes are being built with natural gas or electric heating systems, shrinking the market for heating oil.
Only one company has more than 5.0% of the market share. The industry's high capital requirements partially limit competition.
Consumer demand is localized. Many fuel dealers cater to residential demand in close proximity to consumers, making the industry highly fragmented.
Fuel dealers don't receive direct government assistance. However, some government programs that make fuel more affordable for certain consumers can help spur demand.

Safety risks and environmental hazards bring heavy regulation, as accidents and misuse by fuel dealers can have severe consequences. Several federal, state and local laws regulate the storage, distribution.

market_segmentation.segment_description: This market segment includes households. Residences typically use heating oil for home heating and propane for cooking, central heating and water heating. Propane and heating oil are commonly used to provide energy to areas that natural gas distribution systems do not serve. Regional differences exist in liquefied petroleum (LP) gas and heating oil use. The proportion of revenue generated from residential customers has declined slightly as homeowners in the Northeast switch from heating oil to natural gas. However, older buildings in those regions are also more likely to already be equipped with heating oil tanks.

Fuel dealers also generate a significant revenue share from sales to retailers and wholesalers for resale. This segment, which includes retail stores, hotels, motels and restaurants, uses propane and heating oil for the same purposes as the residential segment. Revenue generated from sales to commercial businesses has remained stable. While new commercial buildings are unlikely to be fitted for running on heating oil or propane, those that already do are less likely than residential homes to be refitted to run on natural gas.

Fuel dealers generate revenue through sales to agricultural, manufacturing, industrial and miscellaneous customers. This segment also uses autogas for machinery and processing equipment. Construction companies purchase diesel, gasoline and other fuels to power the vehicles and construction machinery used during operations. Agricultural customers use propane for crop drying, tobacco curing and weed control as fuel for farm equipment and irrigation pumps. Heating oil is used for conventional building heating. Manufacturing customers purchase heating oil and propane to heat their facilities while using diesel and other vehicular fuels to power equipment and machinery. Manufacturing consumers also increasingly purchase autogas, a liquefied petroleum gas used for automobiles, to power their vehicles.

products_and_services.product_description: Propane is produced as a byproduct of refining crude oil and natural gas processing and is used primarily for water, central heating and outdoor cooking.
This product segment includes heating oil. Heating oil is derived from crude oil processing and is used in boilers and furnaces for central heating.

Other fuels include autogas, a liquefied petroleum gas variant used in automobile combustion engines; kerosene; residual fuel oil; coal; wood and wood pellets, among other less popular vehicular and household fuels. A small portion of revenue is generated through services, including installing, repairing, maintaining and modifying propane and heating oil systems.

tier_1_suppliers: Commercial Building Construction in the US
Natural Gas Distribution in the US
Gasoline & Petroleum Wholesaling in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Oil Drilling & Gas Extraction in the US
tier_1_buyers: Agriculture, Forestry, Fishing and Hunting in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Since propane and heating oil demand is relatively inflexible, lower crude oil prices depress revenue in the short term.
demand_determinants.determinant_description: The world price of crude oil has been very volatile historically. Over the past five years, COVID-19 contributed to the significant fluctuations. Declines in the price of crude oil pose a potential threat to the industry.

business_locations.location_description: The region's high population represents a significant source of demand for various fuels. The Southeast is unique because it is the only US region where most residential central heating is with electric power. As with most of the country, the Southeast uses heating oil and propane fuel for a minimal share of overall building heating. In some states, most notably North Carolina, the continued presence of older buildings fitted to use heating oil fuel means that the region demands a greater quantity of that fuel than any other region.

The Mid-Atlantic region is home to several major cities and commercial hubs like New York City and Philadelphia. Being located in this region allows fuel dealers to efficiently serve a large, densely populated market. This region has a well-established transportation system, with numerous highways, railroads and ports, facilitating easy transportation and distribution of fuel products to local and distant markets, reducing operational costs. Also, this region's heavier reliance on heating fuels during the cold winter months creates a constant demand for fuel products, ensuring a steady customer base for fuel dealers throughout the year.

Though the Fuel Dealers industry is experiencing stiff competition from substitutes such as natural gas, heating oil is still a primary heating source for many New England states. Many older buildings in this region continue to use heating oil because the initial cost of retrofitting a building for natural gas heating tends to be high.

regulations_points.regulation_description: States and the federal government enforce many regulations to minimize the fuel industry's environmental impact. Policies like the Clean Air Act regulate emissions from stationary and mobile sources to slow climate change and protect human health. These regulations often require fuel dealers to implement certain technologies and practices to reduce their environmental footprint. All dealers must meet these standards to continue their operations.

The Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) introduces and enforces safety standards for workplaces across industries, including the Fuel Dealers industry. These regulations aim to prevent work-related injuries, illnesses and deaths. For instance, OSHA's Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response regulations cover safety training and emergency procedures for workers dealing with hazardous materials.

The transportation of fuels, particularly hazardous fuels, is regulated by the US Department of Transportation (DOT). The DOT's Hazardous Materials Regulations (HMR) encompass specifications for packaging, labeling and transportation methods. Fuel dealers must attain requisite permits and adhere to operating protocols and stringent safety standards under these regulations. Non-compliance with these regulations can result in severe fines, penalties and even suspension of business operations.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Federal and state authorities require that new fuel dealers comply with extensive regulatory and licensing agreements, constraining entry into the industry.
The capital costs of starting a new business, such as trucks, storage facilities, propane gas bottles and other equipment, are typically high.

Since the industry's products are substitutable, fuel dealers differentiate themselves through service and efficiency. Fuel dealers can also differentiate themselves by expanding their product offerings.
Fuel dealers must acquire equipment for storing and transporting fuel to customers. This equipment is generally costly, increasing the industry's barriers to entry.

basis_points.basis_description: The industry contends with growing competition from other heating systems. More households are switching to central electric heating because of its safety and advancement, which allows customers to easily control the temperature from their mobile devices.
Fuel dealers are insulated from some competition. Homes and businesses already equipped with oil heating systems aren't likely to be refitted with alternatives.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The industry has low market share concentration. The industry comprises several large companies and thousands of small, independent dealers that sell liquefied petroleum gas and heating oil to a more regional market. More than one-quarter of the businesses in the industry are non-employing operators. This high level of fragmentation contributes to the low level of market share concentration.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Concentration has increased in recent years
concentration_points.concentration_description: Larger companies increasingly acquire smaller, independent fuel suppliers to expand their regional reach. Volatile propane and heating oil prices have encouraged larger companies to purchase smaller dealers to control more market share and better control costs.

Market share concentration differs at the segment level, with the heating oil segment being more fragmented than the propane segment. With a more concentrated customer base, it is more difficult for fuel dealers specializing in heating oil to gain a broad market share.
A big part of the disparity is geographical; heating oil is used primarily in the Mid-Atlantic and New England regions, where fewer homes are connected to natural gas lines than in other regions.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchase Costs Vary Because of the Volatility in Prices
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: The costs of crude oil and natural gas, the primary fuel production inputs, primarily determine purchase prices. Because of this volatility, purchase costs can fluctuate. Over the short run, profit tends to move in line with purchase costs (and counter to movements in revenue), with higher purchase costs reducing profit and lower purchase costs boosting profit.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Wage Costs Represent the Second-Largest Industry Expense
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Fuel dealers rely heavily on their employees to make sales and to transport products to homes and businesses for tank refilling. Fuel dealers have a flexible workforce and can relatively easily shed employees when demand declines. With rising demand, employment has expanded while skilled employees have been retained, contributing to wages.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Fuel Dealers Earn Relatively Low Profits
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Demand for heating oil and propane is inelastic over the short run. In response to the necessity of heating, downstream customers won't substantially alter their consumption of fuels even when prices change drastically. The difference between purchase costs and product price largely determines profits over the short run. When fuel purchase costs rise, fuel.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Fuel dealers must acquire equipment for storing and transporting fuel to customers. This equipment is generally costly, increasing the industry's capital intensity.

volatility_points.volatility_title: The industry exhibits a high to very high degree of revenue volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: Fuel demand is highly inelastic for households and businesses, as water and central heating are necessary for almost all downstream customers. Revenue can fluctuate substantially year over year depending on seasonal weather trends and the prices of crude oil and natural gas inputs.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Crude Oil and Natural Gas Prices Used in Fuel Production Determine Industry Revenue and Profit
volatility_points.volatility_description: When the input prices fall, the cost of manufacturing fuel declines, leading to a fall in their prices. Declining crude oil and natural gas prices also reduce purchase costs. When input prices decline, fuel dealers tend to lower prices to improve their market share and deter customers from switching to natural gas or electric heating.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Remote Tank Monitoring Technology is a Key Innovation
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Remote tank monitoring technology allows fuel dealers to remotely monitor the fuel level in a customer's tank. It can provide real-time insights into fuel consumption patterns and determine when the fuel level drops to a certain point, triggering a refill order.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Innovations in the Types of Fuel
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Many fuel dealers are selling biofuels, which are made from organic materials and are sustainable alternatives to traditional fossil fuels. As consumers become more concerned with the environment, these fuels will become an important form of competition.

FAQs.question: Do your sales depend on the overall health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: While demand for home heating fuel is not price-sensitive, sales of home heating fuels will spike in abnormally cold winters.

FAQs.question: Does your company deal in just one product variety or an array?
FAQs.answer: - Diversified dealers will exhibit lower degrees of revenue volatility, aiding profitability. - Nondiversified dealers will be more subject to output price fluctuations, hindering profitability.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to excess revenue volatility?
FAQs.answer: - Dealers that enter into long-term supply contracts with downstream customers will exhibit more stable revenue. - Dealers that exercise input-price and supply management will have a better time planning future orders and deliveries, boosting potential profitability. - Furthermore, so long as dealers do not end up with excess supply, there is minimal risk in underestimating demand since price increases can be passed onto the consumer.

FAQs.question: Is your company located in proximity to key buying and selling markets?
FAQs.answer: - Dealers located in proximity to key selling markets will exhibit lower transportation costs and higher profitability. - Dealers located in proximity to key input suppliers will exhibit lower purchase costs and higher profitability. - Due to the hazardous nature of fuel products, it is not recommended that they be transported long distances. At a certain point, it becomes uneconomical for a fuel dealer to deliver beyond a geographic radius.

FAQs.question: How is your company leveraging the latest technologies?
FAQs.answer: - Dealers who fail to adopt the latest technologies may become uncompetitive and could be forced to exit the industry. - Dealers can increase operational efficiencies and reduce costs by adopting remote tank monitoring technologies. - Smart metering is helping to monitor consumption and is also contributing to more accurate load forecasting.

FAQs.question: Has your company been able to reduce wage costs via automation?
FAQs.answer: - Labor costs can be reduced by adopting automated inventory management and ordering software, freeing up labor resources. - Dealers leveraging the latest technologies will exhibit higher operating efficiency and higher profitability.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all occupational health and safety requirements are upheld?
FAQs.answer: - Compliant dealers will exhibit lower insurance premiums and costs, boosting profitability. - Noncompliant dealers will be subject to insurance cost increases, undercutting profitability. - Operational costs have swelled in recent years amid a new focus on the health and safety of employees.

FAQs.question: Is your company prepared to adapt to shifting environmental regulations?
FAQs.answer: Producers with a penchant for environmentally friendly methods may be favored by the public, boosting exposure and sales. Noncompliant producers will be subject to fines and penalties, limiting profitability.

FAQs.question: Has your company had any difficulty financing current operations?
FAQs.answer: Dealers that enter into long-term supply contracts will have more stable revenue, enduring price declines better and protecting against profit margin volatility. Operations may become unprofitable quickly if oil prices drop precipitously in a short period of time.

FAQs.question: How does your profit compare to the profit of your biggest competitors?
FAQs.answer: - Dealers that adopt the latest technologies will exhibit higher operating efficiencies. - Dealers that enter into long-term supply contracts will exhibit lower revenue volatility and higher profitability.

FAQs.question: Ensuring pricing policy is appropriate
FAQs.answer: Purchase costs move in line with the price of oil. When high oil prices cause purchase costs to mount, fuel dealers must carefully raise their prices to avoid losing customers. However, the inelastic nature of heating demand ensures that most customers will continue to pay higher prices for the time.

FAQs.question: What do you do to promote local support and to keep your customers returning for follow-up visits? Do you have a strong community presence?
FAQs.answer: Local patronage can help to stave off competition from electricity and natural gas, among other forms of competition. The geographically fragmented markets present in this industry can make it difficult for a fuel dealer to secure a sizeable share of the market.

FAQs.question: How loyal is your customer base? What percentage of revenue is devoted to retaining customers?
FAQs.answer: A loyal customer base is crucial to retaining business when confronted with competition from other fuel dealers or from alternative sources of heating.

FAQs.question: How much revenue do you lose to utilities-based substitute products? Do you have long-term supply contracts in place to protect demand?
FAQs.answer: Fuel dealers compete with utility providers, especially for electricity and natural gas, to provide consumers with power for heating and cooking purposes. Fuel products have an advantage in geographic areas where electricity or natural gas is not easily provided. More specifically, this industry is dominated by regional-specific heating needs, like heating oil for the northeast and electricity for the south.

FAQs.question: How much do you rely on residential demand? Do you actively monitor population and construction trends to anticipate new trends?
FAQs.answer: The residential market represents the industry's largest source of demand for propane, other liquefied petroleum gases and heating oil. As the number of houses rises, revenue rises as well to meet the water and central heating needs of these new homes. However, these new home constructions also can present a threat to the industry since they are often fitted with more efficient, environmentally-friendly natural gas hookups.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor the price of crude oil? How do you minimize the impact of oil price volatility on your revenue and profit?
FAQs.answer: Since demand for propane and heating oil is relatively inflexible, higher crude oil prices tend to expand industry revenue in the short term. However, should fuel prices rise to prohibitive levels, this may encourage customers to retrofit their homes and reduce demand.
